s.text: After the Madness , however, has little such passion; in that, it is true to its title.
In September 1993--less than a year after he'd presided over New York's Court of Appeals--the 63-year-old first-time offender began serving an 11-month term in federal prison.
On one occasion he meets a fellow con whose appeal he denied.
In some communities (though not the rich Long Island ones where judges live), a prison term has become almost a rite of passage, something that young men do.

Now he has published the story of his time inside, After the Madness: A Judge's Own Prison Memoir . It is quite an accomplishment: Wachtler has managed to write an uninteresting book about prison life.
In some communities (though not the rich Long Island ones where judges live), a prison term has become almost a rite of passage, something that young men do.
In some communities (though not the rich Long Island ones where judges live), a prison term has become almost a rite of passage, something that young men do.
They find a code to live by--Islam for Malcolm, black power for Cleaver, a freaky Nietzscheanism for Abbott.
After I finished this worthy and dull book, a distressing thought came to me: Its banality might be the fault neither of the judge nor of the legal profession.
